Beginning of the [[Argentine War of Independence]] against the cities of the [[Viceroyalty of the Río de la Plata]] that resist the change. |URL = }} The '''May Revolution''' ({{lang-es|link=no|Revolución de Mayo}}) was a week-long series of events that took place from May 18 to 25, 1810, in [[Buenos Aires]], capital of the [[Viceroyalty of the Río de la Plata]]. This Spanish colony included roughly the territories of present-day Argentina, Bolivia, Paraguay and Uruguay. The result was the removal of [[Viceroy#Spanish Empire|Viceroy]] [[Baltasar Hidalgo de Cisneros]] and the establishment of a local government, the [[Primera Junta]] (''First Junta''), on May 25. It was the first successful revolution in South American Independence process.
The May Revolution was a direct reaction to Spain's [[Peninsular War]]. In 1808, King [[Ferdinand VII of Spain]] [[Abdications of Bayonne|abdicated]] in favor of [[Napoleon]], who granted the throne to his brother, [[Joseph Bonaparte]]. A [[Supreme Central and Governing Junta of the Kingdom (Spain)|Supreme Central Junta]] led resistance to Joseph's government and the French occupation of Spain, but eventually suffered [[Peninsular War#Napoleon's campaign (October 1808 – January 1809)|a series of reversals]] that resulted in the Spanish loss of the northern half of the country. On February 1, 1810, French troops took Seville and gained control of most of [[Andalusia]]. The Supreme Junta retreated to [[Cadiz]] and dissolved itself, and the [[Supreme Central and Governing Junta of the Kingdom#The Council of Regency of Spain and the Indies|Council of Regency of Spain and the Indies]] replaced it. News of these events arrived in Buenos Aires on May 18, brought by British ships.
Viceroy Cisneros tried to maintain the political status quo, but a group of [[criollo people|criollo]] lawyers and military officials organized an [[open cabildo]] (a special meeting of notables of the city) on May 22 to decide the future of the Viceroyalty. Delegates denied recognition to the Council of Regency in Spain and established a junta to govern in place of Cisneros, since the government that had appointed him Viceroy no longer existed. To maintain a sense of continuity, Cisneros was initially appointed president of the Junta. However, this caused much popular unrest, so he resigned under pressure on May 25. The newly formed government, the Primera Junta, included only representatives from Buenos Aires and invited other cities of the Viceroyalty to send delegates to join them. This resulted in the outbreak of war between the regions that accepted the outcome of the events at Buenos Aires and those that did not.
The May Revolution began the [[Argentine War of Independence]], although no formal declaration of independence was issued at the time and the Primera Junta continued to govern in the name of the deposed king, Ferdinand VII. As similar events occurred in many other cities of the continent, the May Revolution is also considered one of the early events of the [[Spanish American wars of independence]]. Historians today debate whether the revolutionaries were truly loyal to the Spanish crown or whether the declaration of fidelity to the king was a necessary ruse to conceal the true objective—to achieve independence—from a population that was not yet ready to accept such a radical change. [[Argentine Declaration of Independence|A formal declaration of independence]] was finally issued at the [[Congress of Tucumán]] on July 9, 1816.
==Causes== {{Main|Causes of the May Revolution}}
===International causes=== [[File:Joseph-Bonaparte.jpg|thumb|upright|alt=A king dressed with gold clothing|The rule of [[Joseph Bonaparte]] as King of Spain was resisted by Spaniards, and cast doubts on the legitimacy of the Spanish viceroys.]] The United States' [[United States Declaration of Independence|declaration of independence]] from Great Britain in 1776 led [[criollo people|criollos]] (Spanish peoples born in the Americas) to believe that revolution and independence from Spain were feasible.<ref name="Santillan387"/><ref>Moses, pp. 36–37</ref> Between 1775 and 1783, the [[Patriot (American Revolution)|American patriots]] of the [[Thirteen Colonies]] waged the [[American Revolutionary War]] against both the local [[Loyalist (American Revolution)|loyalists]] and the Kingdom of Great Britain, eventually establishing a popular government in the place of the British monarchy. The fact that Spain [[Spain in the American Revolutionary War|aided the colonies]] in their struggle against Britain weakened the idea that it would be a crime to end one's allegiance to the parent state.<ref>Moses, p. 35</ref>
The ideals of the [[French Revolution]] of 1789 spread across Europe and the Americas as well.<ref>Abad de Santillán, pp. 385–386</ref> The overthrow and execution of King [[Louis XVI of France|Louis XVI]] and Queen [[Marie Antoinette]] ended centuries of monarchy and removed the privileges of the nobility. Liberal ideals in the political and economic fields developed and spread through the [[Atlantic Revolutions]] across most of the Western world. The concept of the [[divine right of kings]] was questioned by the French ''[[Declaration of the Rights of Man and of the Citizen]]'', by the oft-quoted statement that "[[all men are created equal]]" in the United States Declaration of Independence and even by the Spanish church.<ref name="Santillan387">Abad de Santillán, p. 387</ref>
However, the spread of such ideas was forbidden in the Spanish territories, as was the sale of related books or their unauthorized possession.<ref name="Johnson155">Johnson, p. 155</ref> Spain instituted those bans when it declared war on France after the execution of Louis XVI and retained them after the peace treaty of 1796.<ref name="Santillan387"/> News of the events of 1789 and copies of the publications of the French Revolution spread around Spain despite efforts to keep them at bay.<ref name="Johnson155"/><ref name="Santillan386">Abad de Santillán, p. 386</ref> Many [[Age of Enlightenment|enlightened]] criollos came into contact with liberal authors and their works during their university studies, either in Europe or at the [[University of Saint Francis Xavier|University of Chuquisaca]] (modern [[Sucre]]).<ref>Moses, p. 29</ref> Books from the United States found their way into the Spanish colonies through Caracas, owing to the proximity of Venezuela to the United States and the West Indies.<ref>Moses, p. 34</ref>
[[File:Declaration independence.jpg|thumb|left|alt=Trumbull's Declaration of Independence portrait|The [[United States Declaration of Independence|US Declaration of Independence]] inspired similar movements in the Spanish colonies in South America.]] The [[Industrial Revolution]] started in Britain, with the use of [[plateway]]s, canals and steam power. This led to dramatic increases in the productive capabilities of Britain,<ref>Mantoux, p. 25</ref> and created a need for new markets to sell its products.<ref name="Santillan390"/> The [[Napoleonic Wars]] with France made this a difficult task, after Napoleon imposed the [[Continental System]], which forbade his allies and conquests to trade with Britain. Thus Britain needed to be able to trade with the Spanish colonies, but could not do so because the colonies were restricted to trade only with their parent state.<ref name="Policy">Kaufmann, p.8</ref> To achieve their economic objectives, Britain initially [[British invasions of the Río de la Plata|tried to invade Rio de la Plata]] and conquer key cities in Spanish America.<ref>Abad de Santillán, p. 391–392</ref> When that failed, they chose to promote the Spanish-American aspirations of emancipation from Spain.<ref name="Policy"/><ref name="Luna, p. 28">Luna, ''...Manuel Belgrano'', p. 28</ref>
The [[mutiny of Aranjuez]] in 1808 led King [[Charles IV of Spain]] to abdicate in favor of his son, [[Ferdinand VII of Spain|Ferdinand VII]].<ref name="Bayonne">Fremont-Barnes, p. 29</ref> Charles IV requested that Napoleon restore him to the throne; instead, Napoleon crowned his own brother, [[Joseph Bonaparte]], as the new Spanish King.<ref name="Bayonne"/><ref>Shumway, p. 19</ref> These events are known as the [[Abdications of Bayonne]]. Joseph's coronation was met with severe resistance in Spain, which started the [[Peninsular War]], and the [[Supreme Central and Governing Junta of the Kingdom|Supreme Central Junta]] took power in the name of the absent king.<ref>Abad de Santillán, pp. 388–390</ref> This also led to Spain switching allegiances from France to Britain.<ref name="Santillan390">Abad de Santillán, p. 390</ref> France eventually invaded Sevilla, and a Council of Regency based in [[Cadiz]] replaced the disbanded Supreme Central Junta.<ref name="Bethell101">Bethell, p. 101</ref>
===National causes=== [[File:La Reconquista de Buenos Aires.jpg|thumb|alt=A battle ending with a general surrendering to another|[[William Carr Beresford]] surrenders to [[Santiago de Liniers]] during the [[British invasions of the Río de la Plata]].]] Spain forbade its American colonies to trade with other nations or foreign colonies, and imposed itself as the only buyer and vendor for their international trade.<ref name="Lunain28">Luna, ''Independencia...'', p. 28</ref> This situation damaged the viceroyalty, as Spain's economy was not powerful enough to produce the huge supply of goods that the numerous colonies would need. This caused economic shortages and recession.<ref name="Lunain28"/><ref>Bethell, p. 1</ref> The Spanish trade routes favored the ports of Mexico and [[Lima]], to the detriment of Buenos Aires.<ref>Shumway, pp. 8–9</ref> As a result, Buenos Aires smuggled those products that could not be obtained legitimately.<ref>Shumway, p. 9</ref> Most local authorities allowed this smuggling as a lesser evil, even though it was illegal, and it occasionally equalled in volume the legal commerce with Spain.<ref name="Abad391">Abad de Santillán, p. 391</ref> Two antagonistic factions emerged: the landowners wanted free trade so they could sell their products abroad, while the merchants, who benefited from the high prices of smuggled imports, opposed free trade because prices would come down.<ref>Shumway, p. 15</ref>
[[File:Carlota Joaquina por Manuel António de Castro.jpg|thumb|left|upright|alt=Black&White portrait of a noble woman|The coronation of ''Infanta'' [[Carlota of Spain|Carlota Joaquina]] was [[Carlotism|considered an alternative to revolution.]]]] The Spanish monarchy appointed their own candidates to most of the political offices in the viceroyalty, usually favoring Spaniards from Europe.<ref name="Shumway3">Shumway, p. 3</ref> In most cases, the appointees had little knowledge of or interest in local issues. Consequently, there was a growing rivalry between criollos and [[peninsulars]] (those born in Spain). Most criollos thought that peninsulars had undeserved advantages and received preferential treatment in politics and society.<ref name="Lunain28"/> The lower clergy had a similar sentiment about the higher echelons of the religious hierarchy.<ref name="Abad391"/> Events developed at a slower pace than in the United States independence movement.<ref name="Moses4"/> This was in part because the clergy controlled the entire educational system in Spanish America, which led the population to hold the same conservative ideas and follow the same customs as in Spain.<ref name="Moses4">Moses, p. 4</ref>
Buenos Aires and [[Montevideo]] successfully resisted two British invasions.<ref name="Luna, p. 28"/> In 1806, a small British army led by [[William Beresford, 1st Viscount Beresford|William Carr Beresford]] seized Buenos Aires for a brief time; a Montevidean army led by [[Santiago de Liniers]] liberated the city.<ref name="Shumway17">Shumway, p. 17</ref> The following year, a larger army seized Montevideo, but was overwhelmed by the forces of Buenos Aires; the invaders capitulated<ref name="Shumway17"/> and returned Montevideo to the viceroyalty. There was no aid from Spain during either invasion.<ref name="Lunain28"/><ref>Luna, ''...Cornelio Saavedra'', pp. 78–79</ref> Liniers organized criollo militias during the preparations for the second invasion, in spite of the prohibition against them.<ref name="Brown257">Brown, p. 257</ref><ref>Abad de Santillán, p. 376</ref><ref>Johnson, p. 264</ref> The [[1st Infantry Regiment (Argentina)|Patricios Regiment]], led by [[Cornelio Saavedra]], was the biggest criollo army. These events gave criollos military power and political influence that they did not have before and, since the victory was achieved without any help from Spain, it boosted criollo confidence in their independent capabilities.<ref name="Lunain28"/><ref>Bethell, p. 94</ref>
The Portuguese royal family left Europe and [[Transfer of the Portuguese Court to Brazil|settled in colonial Brazil]] in 1808, after their escape from the Napoleonic invasion of Portugal.<ref name="Chasteen82">Chasteen, p. 82</ref> [[Carlota of Spain|Carlota Joaquina]], sister of Ferdinand VII, was the wife of the Portuguese prince regent, but had her own political projects.<ref>Chasteen, pp. 82–83</ref> As she avoided the later capture of the Spanish royal family, she attempted to take charge of the viceroyalty as regent.<ref>Chasteen, pp. 82–84</ref> This political project, known as [[Carlotism]], sought to prevent a French invasion of the Americas.<ref name="Santillan394">Abad de Santillán, p. 394</ref> A small secret society of criollos, composed of politicians such as [[Manuel Belgrano]] and [[Juan José Castelli]], and military leaders such as [[Antonio Beruti]] and [[Hipólito Vieytes]], supported this project.<ref name="Bethell95">Bethell, p. 95</ref><ref name="Galasso40">Galasso, p. 40</ref> They considered it an opportunity to get a local government instead of a European one, or a step towards a potential declaration of independence.<ref>Bethell, p. 94–95</ref><ref name="Lunain20">Luna, ''Independencia...'', p. 20</ref> The project was resisted by Viceroy Liniers, most peninsulars, and some criollos, including Cornelio Saavedra and the lawyers [[Mariano Moreno]] and [[Juan José Paso]].<ref name="Bethell95"/><ref name="Lunain20"/> They suspected that it concealed Portuguese expansionist ambitions over the region.<ref name="Bethell95"/> The supporters of Carlota Joaquina intended her to head a [[constitutional monarchy]], whereas she wanted to govern an [[absolute monarchy]]; these conflicting goals undermined the project and led to its failure.<ref name="Bethell95"/><ref name="Galasso40"/> Britain, which had a strong influence in the politics of the Portuguese Empire, opposed the project as well: they did not want Spain split into several kingdoms, and considered Carlota Joaquina unable to prevent this.<ref>Kaufmann, p. 58</ref>
==Prelude==
===Liniers government=== [[File:Santiago de Liniers.jpg|thumb|left|upright|alt=Portrait of Santiago de Liniers|[[Santiago de Liniers, 1st Count of Buenos Aires|Santiago de Liniers]] ruled as viceroy between 1807 and 1809.]] After the British invasion of 1806, [[Santiago de Liniers, 1st Count of Buenos Aires|Santiago de Liniers]] successfully reconquered Buenos Aires.<ref name="Lunabel33">Luna, ''...Manuel Belgrano'', p. 33</ref> The population did not allow [[Rafael de Sobremonte]] to continue as Viceroy.<ref name="Lunabel33"/> He had escaped to Cordoba with the public treasury while the battle was still in progress.<ref>Luna, ''...Manuel Belgrano'', p. 30</ref> A law enacted in 1778 required the treasury to be moved to a safe location in the case of a foreign attack, but Sobremonte was still seen as a coward by the population.<ref name="Lunabre52">Luna, ''Breve...'', p. 52</ref> The [[Royal Audiencia of Buenos Aires]] did not allow his return to Buenos Aires and elected Liniers, acclaimed as a popular hero, as an interim Viceroy.<ref name="Lunabel33"/> This was an unprecedented action, the first time that a Spanish viceroy was deposed by local government institutions, and not by the King of Spain himself;<ref name="Lunabre52"/> King Charles IV ratified the appointment at a later time.<ref>Luna, ''...Santiago de Liniers'', p. 120</ref> Liniers armed the entire population of Buenos Aires, including criollos and slaves, and defeated a second British invasion attempt in 1807.<ref name="Brown257"/>
The Liniers administration was popular among criollos, but not among peninsulars such as the merchant [[Martín de Álzaga]] and the Governor of Montevideo, [[Francisco Javier de Elío]].<ref>Luna, ''...Santiago de Liniers'', p. 128</ref> They requested the Spanish authorities appoint a new viceroy.<ref>Johnson, p. 262</ref> In the wake of the outbreak of the Peninsular War, de Elío created the [[Junta of Montevideo]], which would scrutinise all the orders from Buenos Aires and reserve the right to ignore them, but did not openly deny the authority of the Viceroy or declare Montevideo independent.<ref name="Bethell95"/>
Martín de Álzaga [[Mutiny of Álzaga|began a mutiny]] to remove Liniers.<ref name="Bethell96">Bethell, p. 96</ref> On January 1, 1809, an [[open cabildo]] (an extraordinary meeting of ''[[vecino]]s'', prominent people of the city) chaired by Álzaga demanded the resignation of Liniers and the appointment of a local junta.<ref>Mitre, pp. 264–265</ref> The Spanish militia and a group of people summoned by the meeting gathered to support the rebellion.<ref>Mitre, p. 265</ref> A small number of criollos, notably Mariano Moreno, supported the mutiny,<ref name="Bethell96"/> but most of them did not.<ref name="Lunacast55">Luna, ''...Juan José Castelli'', p. 55</ref> They felt that Álzaga wanted to remove the Viceroy to avoid his political authority while keeping the social differences between criollos and peninsulars unchanged.<ref name="Lunacast55"/> The riot was quickly routed when criollo militias led by Cornelio Saavedra surrounded the plaza and dispersed the insurgents.<ref name="Johnson270">Johnson, p. 270</ref> As a result of the failed mutiny, the rebel militias were disarmed.<ref name="Johnson270"/> This included all peninsular militias, and the power of the criollos increased as a result.<ref name="Johnson270"/> The leaders of the plot, with the exception of Moreno,<ref>Scenna, p. 23</ref> were exiled to [[Carmen de Patagones]].<ref name="Johnson270"/> Javier de Elío freed them and gave them political asylum at Montevideo.<ref>Johnson, pp. 270–271</ref>
===Cisneros government=== [[File:Baltasar Hidalgo de Cisneros.jpg|thumb|upright|alt=Portrait of Viceroy Baltasar Hidalgo de Cisneros|[[Baltasar Hidalgo de Cisneros]], the last viceroy to rule in Buenos Aires.]] The Supreme Central Junta replaced Liniers with the naval officer [[Baltasar Hidalgo de Cisneros]], a veteran of the [[Battle of Trafalgar]], to end the political turmoil in the Río de la Plata.<ref>Luna, ...''Juan José Castelli'', p. 58</ref> He arrived in Montevideo in June 1809 for the handover.<ref>Luna, ...''Juan José Castelli'', pp. 58–59</ref> Manuel Belgrano proposed that Liniers should resist on the grounds that he had been confirmed as Viceroy by a King of Spain, whereas Cisneros lacked such legitimacy.<ref name="Belgrano65">Belgrano, p. 65</ref> The criollo militias shared Belgrano's proposal,<ref name="Belgrano65"/> but Liniers handed over the government to Cisneros without resistance.<ref>Scenna, pp. 23–24</ref> Javier de Elío accepted the authority of the new Viceroy, and dissolved the Junta of Montevideo.<ref>Bethell, p. 95–96</ref> Cisneros rearmed the disbanded peninsular militias, and pardoned those responsible for the mutiny.<ref>Pigna, p. 224</ref> Álzaga was not freed, but his sentence was commuted to house arrest.<ref>Scenna, p. 24</ref>
There was concern about events in Spain and about the legitimacy of local governors in [[Upper Peru]] as well.<ref name="Abad398"/> On May 25, 1809, the [[Chuquisaca Revolution]] deposed [[Ramón García de León y Pizarro]] as Governor of [[Sucre|Chuquisaca]] and replaced him with [[Juan Antonio Alvarez de Arenales]].<ref name="Abad398">Abad de Santillán, p. 398</ref> On July 16, the [[La Paz revolution]], led by Colonel [[Pedro Domingo Murillo]], deposed the Governor of La Paz and elected a new [[Junta Tuitiva de los Derechos del Pueblo|junta]].<ref name="Abad398"/> A swift reaction from the Spanish authorities defeated those rebellions.<ref name="Abad398"/> An army of 1,000 men sent from Buenos Aires found no resistance at Chuquisaca, took control of the city and overthrew the Junta.<ref name="Abad398"/> Murillo tried to defend La Paz, but his 800 militiamen were completely outnumbered by the more than 5,000 soldiers sent from Lima.<ref name="Abad398"/> He and the other leaders were later beheaded, and their heads were exhibited as a deterrent.<ref>Mitre, p. 286</ref> These measures contrasted sharply with the pardon that Martín de Álzaga and others had received after a short time in prison, and the resentment of criollos against the peninsulars deepened.<ref>Chasteen, p. 54</ref> Juan José Castelli was present at the deliberations of the University of Chuquisaca, where [[Bernardo Monteagudo]] developed the ''Syllogism of Chuquisaca'', a legal explanation to justify [[self-governance]]. This influenced his ideas during the "May Week".<ref>Siles Salinas, p. 126</ref>
On November 25, 1809, Cisneros created the Political Surveillance Court to persecute ''[[afrancesado]]s'' (supporters of Joseph Bonaparte) and [[Independence|independentist]]s.<ref>Pigna, p. 227</ref> However, he rejected economist José María Romero's proposal to banish a number of people considered dangerous to the Spanish regime, such as Saavedra, Paso, Vieytes, Castelli and Moreno, among others.<ref>Scenna, p. 26</ref> Romero warned Cisneros against spreading news that might be considered subversive. Criollos felt that soon any pretext would be enough to lead to the outbreak of revolution. In April 1810, Cornelio Saavedra advised to his friends: "it's not time yet, let the figs ripen and then we'll eat them".<ref name="Brevas">{{lang-es|"No es tiempo, dejen ustedes que las brevas maduren y entonces las comeremos"}} Cited by Luna, ''...Cornelio Saavedra'', p. 84</ref> He meant that he would not support rushed actions against the Viceroy, but would do so at a strategically favorable moment, such as when Napoleon's forces gained a decisive advantage in their war against Spain.<ref>Luna, ''...Cornelio Saavedra'', pp. 85–87</ref>
==May Week== [[File:SitiodeCadiz.jpg|thumb|upright|alt=Map of the Spanish city of Cadiz|Map of [[Cádiz]] during the [[Siege of Cádiz|French siege]].]] The May Week was the period of time in Buenos Aires which began with the confirmation of the fall of the Supreme Central Junta and ended with the dismissal of Cisneros and the establishment of the [[Primera Junta]].<ref>Gelman, pp. 17–18</ref>
On May 14, 1810, the British war schooner HMS ''Mistletoe'' arrived at Buenos Aires with European newspapers that reported the dissolution of the Supreme Central Junta the previous January.<ref>Galasso, p. 46</ref> The city of Seville had been [[Siege of Cádiz|invaded]] by French armies, which were already dominating most of the [[Iberian Peninsula]].<ref name="Bethell101"/> The newspapers reported that some of the former members of the Junta had taken refuge on the [[Isla de León]] in Cadiz.<ref name="Santillan404">Abad de Santillán, p. 404</ref> This was confirmed in Buenos Aires on May 17, when the British frigate HMS ''John Paris'' arrived in Montevideo; the most recent newspapers reported that members of the Supreme Central Junta had been dismissed.<ref name="Santillan404"/> The Council of Regency of Cadiz was not seen as a successor of the Spanish resistance but as an attempt to restore absolutism in Spain.<ref name="Galasso43">Galasso, p. 43</ref> The Supreme Central Junta was seen as sympathetic to the new ideas.<ref>Galasso, p. 44</ref> [[Patriot (Spanish American Revolution)|South American patriots]] feared both a complete French victory in the peninsula and an absolutist restoration.<ref name="Galasso43"/> Cisneros monitored the British warships and seized their newspapers, to conceal the news, but a newspaper came into the hands of Belgrano and Castelli.<ref name="Barco">Pigna, p. 228</ref> They spread the news among other patriots and challenged the legitimacy of the Viceroy, who had been appointed by the fallen junta.<ref name="Barco"/> When Cornelio Saavedra, head of the [[regiment of Patricians]], was informed of this news, he decided that it was finally the ideal time to take action against Cisneros.<ref>Saavedra, p. 60</ref> [[Martín Rodríguez (politician)|Martín Rodríguez]] proposed to overthrow the Viceroy by force, but Castelli and Saavedra rejected this idea and proposed the convening of an open cabildo.<ref name="Luna, p. 70">Luna, ''...Juan José Castelli'', p. 70</ref>
===Friday, May 18 and Saturday, May 19=== [[File:Casa de Peña.jpg|thumb|alt=Portrait of a secret revolutionary meeting|Secret meeting of the revolutionaries at the house of [[Nicolás Rodríguez Peña]].]] Although Viceroy Cisneros attempted to conceal the news of the Spanish defeat, the rumor had already spread throughout Buenos Aires.<ref>López, pp. 30–31</ref> Most of the population was uneasy; there was high activity at the barracks and in the Plaza, and most shops were closed.<ref name="López31">López, p. 31</ref> The "Café de Catalanes" and the "Fonda de las Naciones", frequent criollo meeting places, became venues for political discussions and radical proclamations; [[Francisco José Planes]] shouted that Cisneros should be hanged in the Plaza as retribution for the execution of the leaders of the ill-fated La Paz revolution.<ref name="López31"/> People who sympathized with the absolutist government were harassed, but the fights were of little consequence because nobody was allowed to take muskets or swords out of the barracks.<ref>López, p. 39</ref>
The Viceroy, trying to calm the criollos, gave his own version of events in a proclamation.<ref>Johnson, p. 275</ref> He asked for allegiance to King Ferdinand VII, but popular unrest continued to intensify. He was aware of the news, but only said that the situation on the Iberian Peninsula was delicate; he did not confirm the fall of the Junta.<ref name="Santillan404"/> His proposal was to make a government body that would rule on behalf of Ferdinand VII, together with [[Viceroyalty of Peru|Viceroy of Peru]] [[José Fernando de Abascal y Sousa]], Governor of Potosí [[Francisco de Paula Sanz]] and President of the Royal Audiencia of Charcas [[Vicente Nieto]].<ref name="López31"/>
Not fooled by the Viceroy's communiqué, some criollos met at the houses of [[Nicolás Rodríguez Peña]] and Martín Rodríguez.<ref name="Abad406">Abad de Santillán. p. 406</ref> During these secret meetings, they appointed a representative commission composed of Juan José Castelli and Martín Rodríguez to request that Cisneros convene an open cabildo to decide the future of the Viceroyalty.<ref>Luna, ''...Mariano Moreno'', pp. 85–86</ref>
During the night of May 19 there were further discussions at Rodríguez Peña's house.<ref name="López31"/> Saavedra, called by Viamonte, joined the meeting,<ref name="López31"/> which involved military and civilian leaders.<ref name="Lopez44">López, p. 44</ref> They arranged that Belgrano and Saavedra would meet with [[Juan José de Lezica]], the senior [[alcalde]] (municipal magistrate), while Castelli would meet with the procurator [[Julián de Leiva]], to ask for their support.<ref name="López31"/> They asked the Viceroy to allow an open cabildo, and said that if it was not freely granted the people and the criollo troops would march to the Plaza, force the Viceroy to resign by any means necessary, and replace him with a patriot government.<ref name="López31"/> Saavedra commented to Lezica that he was suspected of betrayal because of his constant requests for cautious and measured steps.<ref name="Lopez44" /> This comment was designed to pressure Lezica into speeding up the legal system to allow the people to express themselves, or otherwise risk a major rebellion.<ref name="Lopez44"/> Lezica asked for patience and time to persuade the Viceroy, and leave a massive demonstration as a last resort.<ref name="Lopez32">López, p. 32</ref> He argued that if the Viceroy was deposed in that way, it would constitute a rebellion, which would turn the revolutionaries into outlaws.<ref name="Lopez32"/> Manuel Belgrano gave the following Monday as the deadline to confirm the open cabildo before taking direct action.<ref>López, pp. 44–45</ref> Leiva would later act as a mediator, being both a confidante of Cisneros and a trusted negotiator for the more moderate revolutionaries.<ref name="Galasso, p. 49">Galasso, p. 49</ref>
===Sunday, May 20=== [[File:Castelli y Cisneros.jpg|left|thumb|upright|alt=Engraving of a meeting between Castelli and Cisneros|[[Juan José Castelli]] asks [[Baltasar Hidalgo de Cisneros]] for an open cabildo.]] Lezica informed Cisneros of the request for an open cabildo and the Viceroy consulted Leiva, who spoke in favor of it.<ref name="Abad406"/> The Viceroy summoned military commanders to come to the fort at 7 pm,<ref name="Lopez45">López, p. 45</ref> to demand military support.<ref name="Johnson276">Johnson, p. 276</ref> There were rumors that it could be a trap to capture them and take control of the barracks.<ref name="Lopez45"/> To prevent this, they took command of the grenadiers that guarded the Fort and seized the keys of all entrances while meeting with the Viceroy.<ref name="Lopez45"/> Colonel Cornelio Saavedra, head of the Regiment of Patricios, responded on behalf of all the criollo regiments.<ref name="Saavedra61">Luna, ''Cornelio Saavedra'', pp. 89–91</ref> He compared the current international situation with that prevailing at the time of the mutiny of Álzaga over a year earlier, pointed out that Spain was now almost entirely under Napoleonic control and that the undefeated Spanish provinces were very small in comparison with the Americas.<ref name="Saavedra61"/> He rejected the claim of sovereignty of Cadiz over the Americas,<ref name="Johnson276"/> and concluded that the local armies wanted to look after themselves, rather than following the fate of Spain.<ref name="Saavedra61"/> Finally, he pointed out that the Supreme Central Junta that appointed Cisneros as Viceroy no longer existed, so he rejected Cisneros' legitimacy as Viceroy and denied him the protection of the troops under his command.<ref name="Saavedra61"/>
Castelli and Martín Rodríguez moved to the Fort for an interview with Cisneros.<ref name="Luna, p. 70"/> [[Juan Florencio Terrada]], commander of the Infantry Grenadiers, joined them, because their barracks were located under Cisneros' window, and his presence would not allow the Viceroy to request military aid to take Castelli and Martín Rodríguez prisoners.<ref>De Titto, p. 331</ref> The guards let them pass unannounced, and they found Cisneros playing cards with Brigadier Quintana, prosecutor Caspe and aide Coicolea.<ref name="Luna, p. 70"/> Castelli and Rodríguez demanded once again the convening of an open cabildo, and Cisneros reacted angrily, considering their request an outrage.<ref name="Luna, p. 70"/> Rodríguez interrupted him and forced him to give a definitive answer.<ref name="Luna, p. 70"/> After a short private discussion with Caspe, Cisneros reluctantly gave his consent.<ref>Luna, ''...Juan José Castelli'', p. 71</ref>
That night, many of the revolutionaries attended a theatre production on the theme of tyranny, called ''Rome Saved''.<ref name="Lopez32"/> The lead actor was Morante, playing [[Cicero]].<ref name="Lopez32"/> The police chief requested Morante to feign illness and not appear, so that the play could be replaced with ''Misanthropy and Repentance'' by the German novelist and playwright [[August von Kotzebue]].<ref name="Lopez32"/> Rumors of police censorship spread quickly; Morante ignored the request and performed the play as planned.<ref name="Lopez32"/> In the fourth act, Morante made a patriotic speech, about the Gaul threat to Rome (the [[Gauls]] are ancestors of the [[French people]]) and the need for strong leadership to resist the danger.<ref name="Rome">López, p. 33</ref> This scene lifted the revolutionaries' spirits and led to frenzied applause.<ref name="Rome"/> Juan José Paso stood up and cried out for the freedom of Buenos Aires, and a small fight ensued.<ref name="Rome"/>
After the play, the revolutionaries returned to Peña's house.<ref name="Lopez34">López, p. 34</ref> They learned the result of the meeting with Cisneros, but were unsure as to whether Cisneros intended to keep his word.<ref name="Lopez34"/> They organized a demonstration for the following day to ensure that the open cabildo would be held as decided.<ref name="Lopez34"/>
===Monday, May 21=== [[File:Invitación al Cabildo Abierto.jpg|thumb|upright|alt=Paper detailing an invitation to the open cabildo|Invitation to the open cabildo of May 22]] At 3 pm, the Cabildo began its routine work, but was interrupted by 600 armed men named the Infernal Legion, who occupied the Plaza de la Victoria and loudly demanded the convening of an open cabildo and the resignation of Viceroy Cisneros.<ref name="Johnson276"/> They carried a portrait of Ferdinand VII and the lapels of their jackets bore a white ribbon that symbolized criollo–Spanish unity.<ref>Galasso, pp. 46–47</ref> [[Domingo French]], the mail carrier of the city, and Antonio Beruti, an employee of the treasury, led the rioters.<ref name="Johnson276"/> It was rumored that Cisneros had been killed, and that Saavedra would take control of the government.<ref name="Lopez36">López, p. 36</ref> Saavedra was at the barracks at that moment, concerned about the demonstration.<ref name="Lopez36"/> He thought the violence should be stopped and that radical measures such as the assassination of Cisneros should be prevented, but he also thought that the troops would mutiny if the demonstrations were suppressed.<ref name="Lopez36"/> The people in the Plaza did not believe that Cisneros would allow the open cabildo the next day.<ref name="Lopez48">López, p. 48</ref> Leiva left the Cabildo, and Belgrano, who was representing the crowd, requested a definitive commitment.<ref name="Lopez48"/> Leiva explained that everything would go ahead as planned, but the Cabildo needed time to prepare.<ref name="Lopez48"/> He asked Belgrano to help the Cabildo with the work, as his intervention would be seen by the crowd as a guarantee that their demands would not be ignored.<ref name="Lopez48"/> The crowd left the main hall but stayed in the Plaza.<ref name="Lopez48"/> Belgrano protested about the guest list, which consisted of the wealthiest citizens, and thought that if the poor people were left outside there would be further unrest.<ref>López, pp. 48–49</ref> The members of the Cabildo tried to convince him to give his support, but he left.<ref name="Lopez49">López, p. 49</ref>
Belgrano's departure enraged the crowd, as he did not explain what had happened, and the people feared a betrayal.<ref name="Lopez49"/> Demands for Cisneros' immediate resignation replaced those for an open cabildo.<ref name="Lopez49"/> The people finally settled down and dispersed when Saavedra intervened to say that the claims of the Infernal Legion were supported by the military.<ref>Pigna, p. 232</ref>
The invitations were distributed among 450 leading citizens and officials in the capital.<ref name="Galasso, p. 49"/> The Cabildo compiled the guest list, and tried to guarantee the result, inviting people that would be likely to support the Viceroy.<ref>Luna, ''...Manuel Belgrano'', p. 52</ref> The revolutionaries countered this move with a similar one, so that most people would be against Cisneros instead.<ref name="Galasso4950">Galasso, pp. 49–50</ref> The printer [[Agustín José Donado|Agustín Donado]], supporting the revolutionaries, printed nearly 600 invitations instead of the 450 requested, and distributed the surplus among the criollos.<ref name="Galasso4950"/> During the night, Castelli, Rodríguez, French and Beruti visited all the barracks to harangue the troops and prepare them for the following day.<ref name="Lunacas75">Luna, ''...Juan José Castelli'', p. 75</ref>
===Tuesday, May 22=== [[File:Cabildo abierto.jpg|thumb|alt=Portrait of a debate|An [[open cabildo]] discussed the legitimacy of the viceroy and the new local government that replaced him.]] According to the minutes, only about 251 out of the 450 officially invited guests attended the open cabildo.<ref name="Johnson276"/><ref name="Actas">Actas capitulares...</ref> French and Beruti, in command of 600 men armed with knives, shotguns and rifles, controlled access to the square to ensure that the open cabildo had a majority of criollos.<ref name="Johnson276"/><ref name="Lunacas75"/> All noteworthy religious and civilian people were present, as well as militia commanders and many prominent residents.<ref>Luna, ''...Cornelio Saavedra'', p. 91</ref> The only notable absence was that of Martín de Álzaga, who was still under house arrest.<ref>Scenna, p. 33</ref>
A merchant, José Ignacio Rezábal, attended the open cabildo but, in a letter to the priest Julián S. de Agüero, said that he had some doubts which were shared by other people close to him.<ref name="López5153">López, pp. 51–53</ref> He feared that, no matter which party prevailed in the open cabildo, it would take revenge against the other, the Mutiny of Álzaga being a recent precedent.<ref name="López5153"/> He felt that the open cabildo would lack legitimacy if too many criollos were allowed to take part in it as a result of the aforementioned manipulation of the guest list.<ref name="López5153"/>
The meeting lasted from morning to midnight, including the reading of the proclamation, the debate and the vote.<ref>Mitre, p. 327</ref> There was no secret ballot; votes were heard one at a time and recorded in the minutes.<ref>Galasso, p. 53</ref> The main themes of the debate were the legitimacy of the government and the authority of the Viceroy.<ref name="Lunacas75"/> The principle of [[retroversion of the sovereignty to the people]] stated that, in the absence of the legitimate monarch, power returned to the people; they were entitled to form a new government.<ref name="Luna, Independencia..., p. 32"/> This principle was commonplace in Spanish [[scholasticism]] and [[Rationalism|rationalist philosophy]], but had never been applied in case law.<ref name="Luna, Independencia..., p. 32">Luna, ''Independencia...'', p. 32</ref> Its validity divided the assembly into two main groups: one group rejected it and argued that the situation should remain unchanged; this group supported Cisneros as Viceroy. The other group supported change, and considered that they should establish a [[Junta (Peninsular War)|junta, like the ones established in Spain]] to replace the Viceroy.<ref>Mitre, pp. 315–316</ref> There was also a third position, taking the middle ground.<ref name="Luna, Independencia..., p. 34">Luna, ''Independencia...'', p. 34</ref> The promoters of change did not recognize the authority of the Council of Regency, and argued that the colonies in America were not consulted in its formation.<ref name="Luna, Independencia..., p. 32"/> The debate tangentially discussed the rivalry between criollos and peninsulars; the Viceroy supporters felt that the will of peninsulars should prevail over that of criollos.<ref>Galasso, p. 54</ref>
One of the speakers for the first position was the bishop of Buenos Aires, [[Benito Lue y Riega]], leader of the local church, who said:
<blockquote><span style="font-size:90%;">Not only is there no reason to get rid of the Viceroy, but even if no part of Spain remained unsubdued, the Spaniards in America ought to take it back and resume command over it. America should only be ruled by the natives when there is no longer a Spaniard there. If even a single member of the Central Junta of Seville were to land on our shores, we should receive him as the Sovereign.<ref>{{lang-es|link=no|No solamente no hay por qué hacer novedad con el virrey, sino que aún cuando no quedase parte alguna de la España que no estuviese sojuzgada, los españoles que se encontrasen en la América deben tomar y reasumir el mando de ellas y que éste sólo podría venir a manos de los hijos del país cuando ya no hubiese un español en él. Aunque hubiese quedado un solo vocal de la Junta Central de Sevilla y arribase a nuestras playas, lo deberíamos recibir como al Soberano.}} Cited by Pigna, p. 234</ref></span></blockquote>
[[Juan José Castelli]] was the main speaker for the revolutionaries.<ref name="Abad408"/> He based his speech on two key ideas: the government's lapsed legitimacy—he stated that the Supreme Central Junta was dissolved and had no rights to designate a Regency—and the principle of retroversion of sovereignty.<ref name="Luna, Independencia..., p. 32"/> He spoke after Riega, and replied that the American people should assume control of their government until Ferdinand VII could return to the throne.
<blockquote><span style="font-size:90%;">Nobody could call the whole nation a criminal, nor the individuals that have aired their political views. If the right of conquest belongs by right to the conquering country, it would be fair for Spain to quit resisting the French and submit to them, by the same principles for which it is expected that the Americans submit themselves to the peoples of Pontevedra. The reason and the rule must be equal for everybody. Here there are no conquerors or conquered; here there are only Spaniards. The Spaniards of Spain have lost their land. The Spaniards of America are trying to save theirs. Let the ones from Spain deal with themselves as they can; do not worry, we American Spaniards know what we want and where we go. So I suggest we vote: that we replace the Viceroy with a new authority that will be subject to the parent state if it is saved from the French, and independent if Spain is finally subjugated.<ref>{{Lang-es|link=no|Nadie ha podido reputar por delincuente a la nación entera, ni a los individuos que han abierto sus opiniones políticas. Si el derecho de conquista pertenece, por origen, al país conquistador, justo sería que la España comenzase por darle la razón al reverendo obispo abandonando la resistencia que hace a los franceses y sometiéndose, por los mismos principios con que se pretende que los americanos se sometan a las aldeas de Pontevedra. La razón y la regla tienen que ser iguales para todos. Aquí no hay conquistados ni conquistadores, aquí no hay sino españoles. Los españoles de España han perdido su tierra. Los españoles de América tratan de salvar la suya. Los de España que se entiendan allá como puedan y que no se preocupen, los americanos sabemos lo que queremos y adónde vamos. Por lo tanto propongo que se vote: que se subrogue otra autoridad a la del virrey que dependerá de la metrópoli si ésta se salva de los franceses, que será independiente si España queda subyugada.}} cited by Pigna, p. 236</ref></span></blockquote>
[[Pascual Ruiz Huidobro]] stated that, since the authority that appointed Cisneros had expired, Cisneros should no longer have a place in the government.<ref name="Abad408"/> Huidobro felt that the Cabildo should be in government, as it was the representative of the people.<ref name="Abad408"/> Melchor Fernández, Juan León Ferragut and Joaquín Grigera supported his vote, among others.<ref name="Abad408">Abad de Santillán, p. 408</ref>
[[File:Saavedra 2.jpg|thumb|upright|alt=Portrait of Cornelio Saavedra|The proposal of [[Cornelio Saavedra]] got the majority of votes.]] Attorney [[Manuel Genaro Villota]], representative of the conservative Spanish, said that the city of Buenos Aires had no right to make unilateral decisions about the legitimacy of the Viceroy or the Council of Regency without the participation of other cities of the Viceroyalty.<ref name="Abad408"/> He argued that such an action would break the unity of the country and establish as many sovereignties as there were cities.<ref name="Abad408"/> His intention was to keep Cisneros in power by delaying any possible action.<ref name="Luna, Independencia..., p. 32"/> Juan José Paso accepted his first point, but argued that the situation in Europe and the possibility that Napoleon's forces could conquer the American colonies demanded an urgent resolution.<ref>Pigna, p. 237</ref> He then expounded the "argument of the elder sister", reasoning that Buenos Aires should take the initiative and make the changes deemed necessary and appropriate, on the express condition that the other cities would be invited to comment as soon as possible.<ref name="Lunabre62">Luna, ''Breve...'', p. 62</ref> The rhetorical device of the "elder sister", comparable to ''[[negotiorum gestio]]'',<ref>López, p. 92</ref> makes an analogy between the relationship of Buenos Aires and other cities of the viceroyalty with a sibling relationship.<ref name="Lunabre62"/>
The priest [[Juan Nepomuceno Solá]] then proposed that the Cabildo should receive the provisional command, until the formation of a governing junta made up of representatives from all populations of the Viceroyalty.<ref name="Abad408"/> Manuel Alberti, Miguel de Azcuénaga (who would be members of the Primera Junta some days later), Escalada and Argerich (or Aguirre) supported his vote, among others.<ref name="Abad408"/>
Cornelio Saavedra suggested that the Cabildo should receive the provisional command until the formation of a governing junta in the manner and form that the Cabildo would deem as appropriate.<ref name="Abad408"/> He said "...there shall be no doubt that it is the people that create authority or command."<ref>{{lang-es|...y no quede duda que es el pueblo el que confiere la autoridad o mando}} Cited by Abad de Santillán, p. 408</ref> At the time of the vote, Castelli's position coincided with that of Saavedra.<ref name="resultado">Abad de Santillán, p. 409</ref>
Manuel Belgrano stood near a window and, in the event of a problematic development, he would give a signal by waiving a white cloth, upon which the people gathered in the Plaza would force their way into the Cabildo.<ref name="Belgrano">Galasso, p. 52</ref> However, there were no problems and this emergency plan was not implemented.<ref name="Belgrano"/> The historian [[Vicente Fidel López]] revealed that his father, [[Vicente López y Planes]], who was present at the event, saw that Mariano Moreno was worried near the end in spite of the majority achieved.<ref>Galasso, p. 67</ref> Moreno told Planes that the Cabildo was about to betray them.<ref name="resultado"/><ref>Galasso, pp. 67–68</ref>
===Wednesday, May 23=== The debate took all day, and the votes were counted very late that night.<ref>Galasso, p. 58</ref> After the presentations, people voted for the continuation of the Viceroy, alone or at the head of a junta, or his dismissal. The ideas explained were divided into a small number of proposals, designated with the names of their main supporters, and the people then voted for one of those proposals. The voting lasted for a long time, and the result was to dismiss the Viceroy by a large majority: 155 votes to 69.<ref name="resultado"/>
Manuel José Reyes stated that he found no reason to depose the Viceroy, and that it would be enough to appoint a junta headed by Cisneros.<ref name="Galasso59">Galasso, p. 59</ref> His proposal had nearly 30 votes.<ref name="Galasso59"/> Another 30 votes supported Cisneros, with no change to the political system.<ref name="Galasso59"/> A small group supported the proposal of Martín José de Choteco, who also supported Cisneros.<ref name="Galasso60">Galasso, p. 60</ref>
There were also many different proposals involving the removal of Cisneros.<ref name="Galasso60"/> Many of them required the new authorities to be elected by the Cabildo.<ref name="Galasso60"/> Pascual Ruiz Huidobro proposed that the Cabildo should rule in the interim and appoint a new government, but this proposal made no reference to [[popular sovereignty]] or the creation of a junta.<ref name="Galasso60"/> This proposal received 35 votes, and sought simply to replace Cisneros with Huidobro: Huidobro was the most senior military officer, and thus the natural candidate under current laws to replace the viceroy in the lack of a new appointment from Spain.<ref>Galasso, pp. 61–62</ref> Juan Nepomuceno Solá proposed a junta composed of delegates from all the provinces of the viceroyalty, while the Cabildo should govern in the interim; this proposal received nearly 20 votes.<ref>Galasso, p. 62</ref> Cornelio Saavedra, whose aformentioned proposal was that the Cabildo should appoint a Junta and rule in the interim, got the largest number of votes.<ref>Galasso, p. 64</ref> A number of other proposals received only a few votes each.<ref>Galasso, p. 65</ref>
At dawn on May 23, the Cabildo informed the population that the Viceroy would end his mandate. The highest authority would be transferred temporarily to the Cabildo until the appointment of a governing junta.<ref name="Pigna, p. 238">Pigna, p. 238</ref> Notices were placed at various points throughout the city, which announced the imminent creation of a junta and the summoning of representatives from the provinces.<ref name="resultado"/> The notices also called for the public to refrain from actions contrary to public policy.<ref name="Abad410">Abad de Santillán, p. 410</ref>
===Thursday, May 24=== The Cabildo interpreted the decision of the open cabildo in its own way.<ref name="Abad410"/> When it formed the new Junta to govern until the arrival of representatives from other cities, Leiva arranged for former viceroy Cisneros to be appointed president of the Junta and commander of the armed forces.<ref>Galasso, p. 67–68</ref><ref name="Johnson277">Johnson, p. 277</ref> There are [[Historiography of the May Revolution#Factual concerns|many interpretations]] of his motives for departing from the decision of the open cabildo in this way.<ref name="Luna, Independencia..., p. 34"/><ref name="Abad410"/> Four other members were appointed to the Junta: criollos Cornelio Saavedra and Juan José Castelli, and peninsulars Juan Nepomuceno Solá and [[José Santos Inchaurregui]].<ref name="Abad410"/>
Leiva wrote a constitutional code to regulate the actions of the Junta.<ref name="Abad410"/> It stipulated that the Junta could not exercise judicial power, which was reserved for the Royal Audiencia of Buenos Aires; that Cisneros could not act without the support of the other members of the Junta; that the Cabildo could dismiss anyone who neglected his duty; that the Cabildo's consent would be required to create new taxes; that the Junta would sanction a general amnesty for those who had aired opinions at the open cabildo; and that the Junta would invite the other cities to send delegates.<ref name="Abad410"/> The commanders of the armed forces, including Saavedra and Pedro Andrés García, agreed to this code.<ref name="Abad410"/> The Junta swore the oath of office that afternoon.<ref>López, p 64</ref>
These developments shocked the revolutionaries.<ref name="Lopez48"/> Unsure of what to do next, they feared that they would be punished, like the revolutionaries of Chuquisaca and La Paz.<ref>López, p. 59</ref> Moreno abjured relations with the others and shut himself in his home.<ref name="Lopez60">López, p. 60</ref> There was a meeting at Rodríguez Peña's house.<ref name="Lopez60"/> They felt that the Cabildo would not pursue such a plot without the blessing of Saavedra and that Castelli should resign from the Junta.<ref name="Lopez60"/> Tagle took a different view: he thought that Saavedra may have accepted out of weakness or naivety and that Castelli should stay in the Junta to counter the others' influence on him.<ref name="Lopez60"/> Meanwhile, a mob led by Domingo French and Antonio Beruti filled the Plaza. The stability of Cisneros in power, albeit in an office other than Viceroy, was seen as an insult to the will of the open cabildo.<ref name="Abad410"/> Colonel Martín Rodriguez warned that, if the army were to commit support to a government that kept Cisneros, they would soon have to fire on the people, and that they would revolt.<ref name="Galasso74">Galasso, p. 74</ref> He said that "everyone without exception" demanded the removal of Cisneros.<ref name="Galasso74"/>
That night, Castelli and Saavedra informed Cisneros of their resignation from the newly formed Junta.<ref name="Lopez 66">López, p. 66</ref> They explained that the population was on the verge of violent revolution and would remove Cisneros by force if he did not resign as well.<ref name="Lopez 66"/> They warned that they did not have the power to stop that: neither Castelli to stop his friends, nor Saavedra to prevent the Regiment of Patricians from mutiny.<ref name="Lopez 66"/> Cisneros wanted to wait for the following day, but they said that there was no time for further delays, so he finally agreed to resign.<ref name="Lopez67">López, p. 67</ref> He sent a resignation letter to the Cabildo for consideration on the following day.<ref name="Lopez67"/> Chiclana felt encouraged when Saavedra resigned, and started to request signatures for a manifesto about the will of the people.<ref name="Lopez67"/> Moreno refused any further involvement, but Castelli and Peña trusted that he would eventually join them if events unfolded as they expected.<ref>López, p. 68</ref>
===Friday, May 25=== [[File:El pueblo quiere saber de qué se trata.jpg|thumb|alt=Depiction of the events of May 25|The people gathered in front of the [[Buenos Aires Cabildo]]]] On the morning of May 25, in spite of bad weather,<ref name="Lunain37"/> a crowd gathered in the Plaza de la Victoria, as did the militia led by Domingo French and Antonio Beruti.<ref>Abad de Santillán, p. 411</ref> They demanded the recall of the Junta elected the previous day, the final resignation of Cisneros, and the appointment of a new junta that did not include him.<ref name="Johnson277"/><ref name="Lunain37"/> Historian [[Bartolomé Mitre]] stated that French and Beruti distributed blue and white ribbons, similar to the modern [[cockade of Argentina]], among those present.<ref>Mitre, pp. 341–342</ref> Later historians doubt it, but consider it possible that the revolutionaries used distinctive marks of some kind for identification.<ref>Galasso, p. 81</ref> It was rumored that the Cabildo might reject Cisneros' resignation.<ref name="Lunain37">Luna, ''Independencia...'', p. 37</ref> Because of delays in issuing an official resolution, the crowd became agitated, clamoring that "[[¡El pueblo quiere saber de qué se trata!|the people want to know what is going on!]]".<ref name="Galasso84">Galasso, p. 84</ref>
The Cabildo met at 9 am and rejected Cisneros' resignation.<ref name="Galasso82">Galasso, p. 82</ref> They considered that the crowd had no legitimate right to influence something that the Cabildo had already decided and implemented.<ref name="Galasso82"/> They considered that, as the Junta was in command, the demonstration should be suppressed by force, and made the members responsible for any changes to the resolution of the previous day.<ref name="Lopez67"/> To enforce those orders, they summoned the chief commanders, but these did not obey.<ref name="Galasso83">Galasso p. 83</ref> Many of them, including Saavedra, did not appear.<ref name="Galasso84"/> Those that did stated that they could not support the government order, and that the commanders would be disobeyed if they ordered the troops to repress the demonstrators.<ref name="Galasso83"/>
The crowd's agitation increased, and they overran the chapter house.<ref>López, p. 70–71</ref> Leiva and Lezica requested that someone who could act as spokesman for the people should join them inside the hall and explain the people's desires.<ref name="Lopez71">López, p. 71</ref> Beruti, Chiclana, French and Grela were allowed to pass.<ref name="Lopez71"/> Leiva attempted to discourage the rioter Pancho Planes, but he entered the hall as well.<ref name="Lopez71"/> The Cabildo argued that Buenos Aires had no right to break the political system of the viceroyalty without discussing it with the other provinces; French and Chiclana replied that the call for a Congress had already been considered.<ref name="Lopez71"/> The Cabildo called the commanders to deliberate with them.<ref>López, p. 73</ref> As had happened several times in the last few days, Romero explained that the soldiers would mutiny if forced to fight against the rioters on behalf of Cisneros.<ref>López, pp.74–75</ref> The Cabildo still refused to give up, until the noise of the demonstration was heard in the hall.<ref name="Lopez75">López, p. 75</ref> They feared that the demonstrators could overrun the building and reach them.<ref name="Lopez75"/> Martín Rodríguez pointed out that the only way to calm the demonstrators was to accept Cisneros' resignation.<ref name="Lopez75"/> Leiva agreed, convinced the other members, and the people returned to the Plaza.<ref name="Lopez75"/> Rodríguez headed to Azcuenaga's house to meet the other revolutionaries to plan the final stages of the revolution.<ref name="Lopez75"/> The demonstration overran the Cabildo again, and reached the hall of deliberations.<ref name="Lopez76">López, p. 76</ref> Beruti spoke on behalf of the people, and said that the new Junta should be elected by the people and not by the Cabildo.<ref name="Lopez76"/> He said that, besides the nearly 400 people already gathered, the barracks were full of people who supported them, and he threatened that they would take control, by force if necessary.<ref name="Lopez77">López, p. 77</ref> The Cabildo replied by requesting their demands in writing.<ref name="Lopez77"/>
[[File:Primera Junta, litografía.jpg|thumb|left|alt=Allegoric images of the members of the Primera Junta|Members of the [[Primera Junta]]]] After a long interval, a document containing 411 signatures was delivered to the Cabildo.<ref name="Crow457">Crow, p. 457</ref> This paper proposed a new composition for the governing Junta, and a 500-man expedition to assist the provinces. The document—still preserved—listed most army commanders and many well-known residents, and contained many illegible signatures. French and Beruti signed the document, stating "for me and for six hundred more".<ref name="Lunain37"/> However, there is no unanimous view among historians about the [[Historiography of the May Revolution#Factual concerns|authorship of the document]].<ref>Scenna, pp. 38–47</ref> Meanwhile, the weather improved and the sun broke through the clouds.<ref name="Crow457"/> The people in the plaza saw it as a favorable omen for the revolution.<ref name="Crow457"/> The ''[[Sun of May]]'' was created a few years later with reference to this event.<ref name="Crow457"/>
The Cabildo accepted the document and moved to the balcony to submit it directly to the people for ratification.<ref name="Lopez77"/> But, because of the late hour and the weather, the number of people in the plaza had declined.<ref name="Lopez78"/> Leiva ridiculed the claim of the remaining representatives to speak on behalf of the people.<ref name="Lopez78">López, p. 78</ref> This wore the patience of the few who were still in the plaza in the rain.<ref name="Lopez78"/> Beruti did not accept any further delays, and threatened to call people to arms.<ref name="Lopez78"/> Facing the prospect of further violence, the popular request was read aloud and immediately ratified by those present.<ref name="Lopez78"/>
The Primera Junta was finally established. It was composed by president Cornelio Saavedra, members [[Manuel Alberti]], [[Miguel de Azcuénaga]], Manuel Belgrano, Juan José Castelli, [[Domingo Matheu]] and [[Juan Larrea (politician)|Juan Larrea]], and secretaries Juan José Paso and Mariano Moreno. The rules governing it were roughly the same as those issued the day before, with the additional provisions that the Cabildo would watch over the members of the Junta and that the Junta itself would appoint replacements in case of vacancies.<ref>López, p. 79</ref> Saavedra spoke to the crowd, and then moved on to the Fort, among salvos of artillery and the ringing of bells.<ref>López, p. 81</ref> Meanwhile, Cisneros dispatched a post rider to [[Córdoba, Argentina]], to warn Santiago de Liniers about what had happened in Buenos Aires and to request military action against the Junta.<ref name="Santillan424">Abad de Santillán, p. 424</ref>
==Aftermath== {{Main|Primera Junta}} {{further|Argentine War of Independence}} [[File:Primera Junta.jpg|thumb|alt=Portrait of the Primera Junta|The [[Primera Junta]] ruled after the revolution.]] Buenos Aires endured the whole Spanish American Wars of independence without being reconquered by royalist armies or successful royalist counter-revolutions.<ref name="Bethell116">Bethell, p. 116</ref> However, it faced several internal conflicts.<ref name="Bethell116"/> The May Revolution lacked a clear [[Libertadores|leader]] as other regions of Latin America; the secretary Mariano Moreno led the initial phase of the government, but he was removed shortly afterwards.<ref>Bethell, pp. 116–117</ref>
The Council of Regency, the Royal Audiencia of Buenos Aires and the peninsulars opposed the new situation.<ref name="Lunain46">Luna, ''Independencia...'', p. 46</ref> The Royal Audiencia secretly swore allegiance to the Council of Regency a month later and sent communiqués to the other cities of the Viceroyalty, to request them to deny recognition to the new government.<ref>Luna, ''Independencia...'', p. 48</ref> To put an end to these activities, the Junta assembled Cisneros and all the members of the Royal Audiencia on the pretext that their lives were in danger, and sent them into exile aboard the British ship ''Dart''.<ref>Luna, ''Independencia...'', p. 47</ref> Captain Mark Brigut Larrea was instructed to avoid American ports and deliver all of them directly to the Canary Islands. The Junta then appointed a new Audiencia composed entirely of criollos loyal to the revolution.<ref name="Bethell116"/><ref>Luna, ''Independencia...'', p.49</ref>
Every city in the territory of modern Argentina other than Córdoba endorsed the Primera Junta.<ref name="Bethell103"/> The cities of the Upper Peru, however, did not take a position, owing to the recent outcomes of the Chuquisaca and La Paz Revolutions. [[Asunción del Paraguay]] rejected the Junta and swore loyalty to the Council of Regency.<ref name="Bethell103"/> The [[Banda Oriental]], under Francisco Javier de Elío, remained a royalist stronghold.<ref name="Bethell103"/>
Former Viceroy [[Santiago de Liniers, 1st Count of Buenos Aires|Santiago de Liniers]] [[Liniers Counter-revolution|organized a counter-revolution]] in Córdoba, and this became the first military campaign of the independent government.<ref name="Bethell116"/> Despite the importance of Liniers himself, and his prestige as a popular hero for his role when the British invaded, the population of Córdoba preferred to support the revolution.<ref name="Domina80">Dómina, p. 80</ref> This reduced the power of the counter-revolutionary army by means of desertions and sabotage.<ref name="Domina80"/><ref name="LunaMore108">Luna, ''...Mariano Moreno'', p. 108</ref> Liniers's troops were quickly defeated by the forces led by [[Francisco Ortiz de Ocampo]].<ref>Abad de Santillán, p. 425</ref> Ocampo refused to shoot the captive Liniers; hence the execution ordered by the Junta was carried out by Juan José Castelli.<ref name="LunaMore108"/> After the victory, the Primera Junta sent military expeditions to many other cities, to demand support and the election of representatives to it.<ref>Santillán, pp. 426</ref>
[[File:Mariano Moreno en su mesa de trabajo.jpg|thumb|left|alt=Portrait of Mariano Moreno|[[Mariano Moreno]] was an influential member of the Primera Junta.]] Montevideo, which had a historical rivalry with Buenos Aires, opposed the Primera Junta and the Council of Regency declared it the new capital of the Viceroyalty, along with Francisco Javier de Elío as the new Viceroy.<ref>Luna, ''Independencia...'', p. 51–52</ref> The city was well defended, so it could easily resist an invasion. Peripheral cities in the Banda Oriental acted contrary to Montevideo's will and supported the Buenos Aires Junta.<ref>Luna, ''Independencia...'', p. 52</ref> [[José Gervasio Artigas]] led them, and kept Montevideo under siege.<ref>Luna, ''Independencia...'', p. 62</ref> The final defeat of the Montevidean royalists was carried out by [[Carlos María de Alvear]] and [[William Brown (admiral)|William Brown]].<ref>Santillán, p. 516</ref>
The [[Captaincy General of Chile]] followed a process analogous to that of the May Revolution, and elected a [[Government Junta of Chile (1810)|Government Junta]] that inaugurated the brief period known as ''[[Patria Vieja]]''. The Junta was defeated in 1814 at the [[Battle of Rancagua]], and the subsequent [[Reconquista (Chile)|Reconquista]] of Chile would make it a royalist stronghold once more. The Andes provided an effective natural barrier between the Argentine revolutionaries and Chile, so there was no military confrontation between them until the [[Crossing of the Andes]], led by [[José de San Martín]] in 1817, a campaign that resulted in the defeat of the Chilean royalists.<ref>Luna, ''Independencia...'', pp. 108–116</ref>
The Primera Junta increased in size when it incorporated the representatives sent by the provinces.<ref>Bethell, p. 117</ref> From then on, the Junta was renamed the ''[[Junta Grande]]''.<ref>Luna, ''Independencia...'', pp. 61–62</ref> It was dissolved shortly after the June 1811 defeat of the Argentine troops at the [[Battle of Huaqui]], and two successive triumvirates exercised executive power over the [[United Provinces of the Río de la Plata]].<ref>Luna, ''Independencia...'', p. 63</ref> In 1814, the [[Second Triumvirate (Argentina)|second triumvirate]] was replaced by the authority of the [[Supreme Director of the United Provinces of the Río de la Plata|Supreme Director]].<ref>Luna, ''Independencia...'', pp.77–86</ref> Meanwhile, [[Martín Miguel de Güemes]] contained the royalist armies sent from the [[Viceroyalty of Peru]] at [[Salta]], while San Martín advanced towards the royalist stronghold of Lima by sea, on a Chilean–Argentine campaign. The war for independence gradually shifted towards northern South America.<ref>Luna, ''Independencia...'', pp. 116—126</ref> From 1814, Argentina [[Argentine Civil Wars|descended into civil war]].<ref>Abad de Santillán, pp. 524-525</ref>
===Consequences=== {{main|Rise of the Argentine Republic}} According to historian [[Félix Luna]]'s ''[[Breve historia de los Argentinos]]'' ({{lang-es|Brief history of the Argentines}}), one of the most important societal consequences of the May Revolution was the shift in the way the people and its rulers related.<ref name="LunaB65">Luna, ''Breve...'', p. 65</ref> Until then, the conception of the common good prevailed: while royal authority was fully respected, if an instruction from the crown of Spain was considered detrimental to the common good of the local population, it was half-met or simply ignored.<ref name="LunaB65"/> With the revolution, the concept of common good gave way to that of popular sovereignty, as theorized by Moreno, Castelli and Monteagudo, among others.<ref>Luna, ''Breve...'', pp. 65–66</ref> This idea held that, in the absence of a legitimate authority, the people had the right to appoint their own leaders.<ref name="LunaB66">Luna, ''Breve..'', p. 66</ref> Over time, popular sovereignty would give way to the idea of [[majority rule]].<ref name="LunaB66"/> This maturation of ideas was gradual, taking many decades to crystallize into stable electoral and political systems, but it was what ultimately led to the adoption of the [[republic|republican system]] as the form of government for Argentina.<ref name="LunaB66"/> [[Domingo Faustino Sarmiento]] stated similar views in his ''[[Facundo]]'', and noted that cities were more receptive to republican ideas, while rural areas were more resistant to them, which led to the surge of [[caudillo]]s.<ref>Sarmiento, p. 79</ref>
Another consequence, also according to Luna, was the [[dissolution of the Viceroyalty of the Río de la Plata]] into several different units.<ref name="LunaB66"/> Most of the cities and provinces had distinctive populations, economies, attitudes, contexts, and interests.<ref name="LunaB66"/> Until the revolution, all of these peoples were held together by the authority of the Spanish government, but with its disappearance, people from Montevideo, Paraguay and the Upper Peru began to distance themselves from Buenos Aires.<ref>Luna, ''Breve...'', p. 67</ref> The brief existence of the Viceroyalty of the Rio de la Plata, which had lasted barely 38 years, impeded the consolidation of a patriotic feeling and failed to bring a sense of community to all of the population.<ref name="LunaB66"/> The new country of Argentina lacked an established concept of national identity capable to unite the population under a common idea of statehood.<ref>Shumway, pp. 3–4</ref> [[Juan Bautista Alberdi]] sees the May Revolution as one of the early manifestations of the power struggles between the city of Buenos Aires and the provinces—one of the axial conflicts at play in the [[Argentine civil wars]].<ref name="Domina845">Dómina, pp. 84–85</ref> Alberdi wrote in his book "''Escritos póstumos''":
<blockquote><span style="font-size:90%;">The revolution of May 1810 in Buenos Aires, intended to win the independence of Argentina from Spain, also had the consequence of emancipating the province of Buenos Aires from Argentina or, rather, of imposing the authority of this province upon the whole nation emancipated from Spain. That day, Spanish power over the Argentine provinces ended and that of Buenos Aires was established.<ref name="Domina845"/></span></blockquote>
==Historical perspectives== {{Main|Historiography of the May Revolution}} [[Historiography|Historiographical]] studies of the May Revolution do not face many doubts or unknown details. Most of the information was properly recorded at the time and was made available to the public by the Primera Junta as patriotic propaganda. Because of this, historical views on the topic differ in their interpretations of the meanings, causes and consequences of the events, rather than in the accuracy of their depiction of the events themselves. The modern version of events does not differ significantly from the contemporary one.<ref>Archer, pp. 3–5</ref>
[[File:BartolomeMitre002.JPG|thumb|upright|alt=Portrait of Bartolome Mitre|[[Bartolomé Mitre]] wrote one of the first historical interpretations of the May Revolution.]] The first people to write about the May Revolution were participants who wrote memoirs, biographies and diaries.<ref name="Gelman32">Gelman, p. 32</ref> However, their works were motivated by purposes other than historiographic ones, such as to explain the reasons for their actions, clean their public images, or express their support or rejection of the public figures and ideas of the time.<ref name="Gelman32"/> For example, [[Manuel Moreno]] wrote the biography of his brother Mariano as propaganda for the revolutions in Europe,<ref>Gelman, pp. 53–54</ref> and Cornelio Saavedra wrote his autobiography at a moment when his image was highly questioned, to justify himself to his sons.<ref>Saavedra, pp. 105–106</ref>
The first remarkable historiographical school of interpretation of the [[history of Argentina]] was founded by members of the [[1837 generation]], including Bartolomé Mitre.<ref>Poli Gonzalvo, pp. 19–20</ref> Mitre regarded the May Revolution as an iconic expression of political egalitarianism: a conflict between modern freedoms and oppression represented by the Spanish monarchy, and an attempt to establish a national organization on constitutional principles as opposed to the [[charismatic authority]] of the caudillos.<ref name="inconclusa">Poli Gonzalvo, p. 22</ref> These authors' views were treated as canonical until the end of the 19th century, when the proximity of the centennial encouraged authors to seek new perspectives.<ref>Gelman, p. 187</ref> The newer authors would differ about the relative weight of the [[causes of the May Revolution]] and about whose intervention in the events was more decisive, but the main views expressed by Mitre were kept,<ref name="Gelman191">Gelman, p. 191</ref> such as to consider the revolution to be the birth of modern Argentina<ref>Gelman, p. 16</ref> and an unavoidable event.<ref>Gelman, p.17</ref> These authors introduced the idea of popular intervention as another key element.<ref name="Gelman191"/> By the time of the World Wars, liberal authors attempted to impose an ultimate and unquestionable historical perspective; [[Ricardo Levene]] and the ''[[National Academy of History of Argentina|Academia Nacional de la Historia]]'' were exponents of this tendency, which still kept most perspectives of Mitre.<ref name="Gelman, p. 256">Gelman, p. 256</ref> Left-wing authors took a [[historical revisionism|revisionist]] view based on nationalism and [[anti-imperialism]]; they minimized the dispute between criollos and peninsulars and portrayed events as a dispute between enlightenment and absolutism.<ref>Gelman, p.257</ref> However, most of their work was focused on other historical periods.<ref name="Gelman, p. 256"/>
The May Revolution was not the product of the actions of a single political party with a clear and defined agenda, but a convergence of sectors with varying interests.<ref>Galasso, p. 86</ref> Thus, there are a number of conflicting perspectives about it, because different authors highlight different aspects.<ref>Galasso, pp. 86–87</ref> Mitre, for example, referred to ''[[The Representation of the Landowners]]'' (an 1809 economic report by Mariano Moreno) and the role of the merchants to support the view that the May Revolution intended to obtain [[free trade]] and [[economic integration]] with Europe;<ref name="Galasso87">Galasso, p. 87</ref> right-wing revisionists center around Saavedra and the social customs of the time to describe the revolution under conservative principles;<ref name="Galasso87"/> and left-wing revisionists use the example of Moreno, Castelli and the rioters led by French and Beruti to describe it as a [[Political radicalism|radical]] revolution.<ref name="Galasso87"/>
===Revolutionary purposes=== [[File:Ferdinand VII of Spain (1814) by Goya.jpg|thumb|alt=Portrait of Ferdinand VII|The revolutionaries of the May Revolution declared loyalty to [[Ferdinand VII of Spain|Ferdinand VII of Spain]].]] The government created on May 25 pronounced itself loyal to the deposed King of Spain Ferdinand VII, but historians disagree on whether this was sincere or not.<ref name="Bethell103">Bethell, p. 103</ref> Since Mitre, many historians think that this professed loyalty was merely a political deception to gain autonomy.<ref>Mitre, pp. 325–326</ref><ref>Luna, ''...Mariano Moreno'', p. 25</ref><ref>Bethell, p. 106–107</ref><ref>Halperín Donghi, p. 96</ref> The Primera Junta did not pledge allegiance to the Council of Regency, which was still in operation, and in 1810 it still seemed unlikely that Napoleon would be defeated and Ferdinand returned to the throne (which finally happened on December 11, 1813, with the [[Treaty of Valençay]]).<ref name="Pigna243">Pigna, p. 243</ref> The purpose of such a deception would have been to gain time to strengthen the position of the patriotic cause and avoid reactions that may have led to a counter-revolution, by making it appear that monarchical authority was still respected and that no revolution had taken place. The ruse is known as the "Mask of Ferdinand VII". It was upheld by the Primera Junta, the Junta Grande and the First Triumvirate. The [[Asamblea del Año XIII|Assembly of Year XIII]] was intended to declare independence, but failed to do so because of other political conflicts between its members.<ref>Pigna, p. 377</ref> However, it suppressed mention of Ferdinand VII in official documents.<ref>Luna, ''Independencia...'', p. 82</ref> Before the [[Argentine Declaration of Independence|declaration of independence of 1816]], the supreme directors considered other options, such as to negotiate with Spain or become a British [[protectorate]].<ref>Fermín Chávez</ref>
The change was potentially favorable for Britain, as trade with the cities of the area was facilitated, without the monopoly that Spain had maintained over their colonies for centuries.<ref>Kaufmann, p. 49</ref> However, Britain's first priority was the war against France in Europe, and they could not appear to support American independence movements or allow the military attention of Spain to be divided onto two different fronts.<ref>Bethell, p. 106</ref> Consequently, they pushed to avoid explicit independence demonstrations.<ref>Bethell, p. 107</ref> This pressure was exerted by [[Lord Strangford]], the British ambassador at the court of Rio de Janeiro; he expressed support for the Junta, but under the condition that "...the behavior is consistent, and that [the] Capital [is] retained on behalf of Mr. Dn. Ferdinand VII and his legitimate successors".<ref>{{lang-es|link=no|siempre que la conducta de esa Capital sea consecuente y se conserve a nombre del Sr. Dn. Fernando VII y de sus legítimos sucesores}} (Strangford), cited by Guiñazú, p. 130</ref> Later conflicts between Buenos Aires, Montevideo and Artigas led to internal conflicts on the British front, between Strangford and the Portuguese regent [[John VI of Portugal|John VI of Portugal]].<ref>Kaufmann, p. 59</ref>
Juan Bautista Alberdi and later historians such as [[Norberto Galasso]],<ref name="Galasso87"/> [[Luis Romero (historian)|Luis Romero]] and [[José Carlos Chiaramonte]]<ref name=Fonrouge2009>Fonrouge</ref> doubted Mitre's interpretation and put forward different ones. Alberdi thought that "the Argentine revolution is a chapter of the Hispanoamerican revolution, as also of the Spanish one, as also of the French and European one".<ref>Alberdi, pp. 64–69</ref> They did not consider it a dispute between independentism and colonialism, but instead a dispute between new libertarian ideas and absolutism.<ref name="Santillan413">Abad de Santillán, p. 413</ref> The intention was not to cut ties with Spain, but to reformulate the relationship; similarly, the [[American Revolution]] was not separatist at its initial steps either.<ref name="Santillan413"/> Thus, it would have the characteristics of a civil war instead.<ref>Galasso, p. 23</ref> Some points that would justify the idea would be the inclusion of Larrea, Matheu, and Belgrano in the Junta and the later appearance of José de San Martín: Larrea and Matheu were Spanish, Belgrano studied for many years in Spain,<ref>Galasso, pp. 10–11</ref> and San Martín had spent most of his adult life waging war in Spain against the French.<ref>Galasso, p. 12</ref> When San Martín talked about enemies, he called them "[[Royalist (Spanish American Revolution)|royalists]]" or "Goths", but never "Spanish".<ref>Galasso, p. 11</ref>
